Form No. 101
MEMORANDUM

I return herewith voucher No.17 for $500.13 in favour of F. H. Lepper and Company and beg to say that the account of $26.77 would not appear to be a charge against P.W.O.A. funds. It apparently is for some repair work in the old section of the building.

In connection with the charge of $208.36, "Extra to contract", I beg to say that this firm's contract of $1,043.00 is for installing plumbing in the new addition to the building and there is nothing to show that it does not include the work billed for in the account of $208.36. If they are entitled to this extra payment it should be approved by the Minister. Kindly see your memorandum of January 18 in which you state that the three prices submitted including the one from F.H. Lepper and Company are for additional plumbing required in alterations and additions.

Representative of the Treasury.
Morley, Alta., May 9th, 1935.

R. Guernsey Orr Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Re- Indian School at Morley.

Dear Mr. Orr:

As the work on the above building nears completion, the Rev. Mr. Staley, Principal, has requested me to bring to your attention a few additional matters pertaining to the school.

You will recall that when you last visited this school he mentioned the need for more lavatory accommodation in the boys' basement consisting of more wash-basins, and two more toilets, and it was suggested that these services be placed in the room off the play-room then used as a kitchen store-room. You replied that this matter had better be deferred until towards the completion of the building, by which time it could be seen if any money would then be available.

As a result of the alterations in the older building, the room formerly used as the Principal's office has been retained as a kitchen store-room in place of the basement store-room, and it is in this latter room that the suggested lavatory fixtures be located.

F.H. Lepper & Co., who installed the plumbing in the new addition of the school, quote a price of $150.00 to provide "one large wash-sink, F-6482-A Standard Sanitary Catalogue, 3 ft long—this sink being equal to 3 basins." This firm also quote a price of $150.00 to install two toilets in the same room, or $105.00 for one toilet, including the necessary drains, traps and vents. Prices quoted are exclusive of the breaking and making good of the concrete floor. To install the wash-basins and two toilets as quoted, plus the floor work, and plus the toilet stalls, would bring the cost of these services up to approximately $350.00, or to about $295.00 if only one toilet were supplied.

Rev. Mr. Staley has also asked me to mention that the matter of renewal of defective wood floors has been in abeyance for some time, and had been asked for in their estimates. These floors are badly worn, and he would like to know if they can be replaced with new flooring where necessary. To meet his request would require about 2000' of E.G. fir flooring, and the labour and materials would amount to about $250.00.

A third request is for the replacement of the platform and steps at the rear of the school, being the boys' entrance to the basement play-room. These steps and platform are now falling to pieces, and if rebuilt might better be done in concrete. We have just about enough cement and gravel on hand to do this work, and could thus be done at no great cost, probably for $25.00.

We have already had to do a great deal of inescapable work in the existing building, and this added to the work called for in the new addition, in labour and materials, leave no margin for the additional requests, unless this further outlay be authorized. I am therefore passing on these requests to the Department, and will await your instructions before undertaking this further outlay.
In the event of the Department granting the request for the additional wash-basins for the boys, it is proposed to transfer the three existing wash-basins in the boys' play-room to the girls' basement play-room to supplement the three basins there, which change would entail but a nominal cost. There would then be the equivalent of 8 wash-basins in the boys' basement lavatory, and 6 basins in the girls' end, which the Principal says would be about right.

My 4 carpenters are now working at making the cupboards, lockers, shelving, new dining-room tables and benches, etc.; and 4 painters are doing the outside painting of the old building and new addition. The building will look immeasurably better in its new colours.

Last Sunday Dr. G.D. Stanley, M.P., paid a visit to this Reserve, and he told me next day how very pleased he is over the way the money granted has been expended here, and the good value obtained in the new buildings. He addressed a large gathering of Indians and whites in the church, it being a Silver Jubilee service.

On the advice of Mr. Christianson, I have deferred my trip to Grouard until the 13th instant in consequence of another heavy fall of snow on the 6th, and he feared there might be still more snow farther north. The snow hereabouts is now all gone except the heavy drifts, and by next week the conditions should be favourable for my inspection of St. Bruno's School. I will report promptly after my inspection. I expect to be absent from Morley for about a week.

Awaiting your valued instructions regarding the foregoing requests of the Reverend Principal of the Morley school,

Your obedient servant

Building Supervisor.
Morley, Alta. April 30th,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Report on Addition to Indian School.

Sir:

Nearly all the work indicated as yet to be done in my Report of the 3rd instant is now completed, and the new rooms provided are now in occupation.

The plasterers returned on the 23rd instant, and spent a busy week plastering the new partition separating the enlarged boys' and girls' dormitories, the lavatory extension, the old and new stair areas, and considerable patching in the older building. Also, while here, they repaired the ceilings of the class-rooms building where plaster had fallen. All this work is now completed, and has been well done by the plastering contractors, Jonathan & Sons, of Calgary.

The basement floor of the new addition has also been laid, and the plastering contractors did the trowelling of the finish coat, some of which had to be done in overtime hours so as to catch the cement at the right stage. We used "Master Mix" concrete hardener on this floor, so as to insure a hard dust-proof surface. It took 10 gals, costing $1.90 per gal.

The Department authorized an extra expenditure of $125.00 to provide a stage off the new basement, for which object we left an opening of 14" in the centre of the divisional wall. This stage will have a lumber floor 13" higher than the basement level, and be provided with accordion doors hung from an overhead track. This work has yet to be done.

The metal ceilings throughout the new addition are now completed, and look very well. We have painted them white. I was able to give them a variety of pleasing patterns without extra cost. It was necessary to renew the metal ceilings in the existing building in places where excessive corrosion had taken place, and a great deal of patching had to be done where the furnace pipes and risers had passed through.

The electrical work has also been completed. The electrical contractor, Mr. Lloyd Orr, of Calgary, carried out this work very efficiently, doing both the wiring of the new addition in conduit, and supplying and hanging the fixtures. It was necessary to change and extend the gong wiring and bells; and to make a number of changes in the existing building to improve the service, and to comply with the more recent requirements of the Electric Code. The Underwriters' Inspector, Mr. R.Wagner, checked over the work, and issued the required certificate.
I was duly advised by the Indian Agent that authority had been granted to spend $750.00 on cupboards, lockers, shelving, etc., and a start is being made today in providing these requirements. It will take tight squeezing to get this work done for the sum allowed as there was an entire absence of lockers in the existing building, and a shortage of tables and cupboards.

The plumbing contractor, F.H. Lepper & Co., of Calgary, is now setting up the plumbing fixtures in the lavatory extension and dormitory, this work having been deferred until the completion of the plastering, and it will be completed tomorrow. The plumbing service in the new dormitory has been in operation for some time. Certain repairs in the plumbing of the existing building seemed unavoidable, and have been done while the plumber was on the job. For instance, the floor drain in the boy's basement play-room beside the wash-basins has been long out of commission, so I had the concrete broken and an examination made. This revealed that the trap was broken and the drain blocked, so I am having a new trap installed and this service restored. Other repairs of like nature will have been noted in the plumber's accounts. I felt sure it was the Department's intention that all services be left in good working order in the old as well as in the new building, and I have given orders accordingly.

I was also advised of the authority to re-paint the walls, roof and trim of the existing building so that the entire structure would conform with the colours of the adjacent Department buildings. This outside painting is well started, but is being much interrupted by unfavourable weather. We are experiencing one of the most backward seasons on record, and even today, the last day of April, we are getting a further fall of snow, and the ground is as white as in mid-winter. The inside painting and staining is now well advanced, and as soon as the weather permits, we shall resume the outside painting. I am employing two Indians to help with the outside painting, but am unable to use them on interior work. Two competent white painters are doing the inside work, now nearly completed.

The new heating plant is proving very advantageous compared with the former hot air furnaces. The Danham Heating Co.'s engineer, Mr. Alex. Walker, who has recently returned from Ottawa, intends to visit the job again, and make a final check of the heating service; and I am also arranging for an early visit of the Provincial Boiler Inspector who will inspect the two boilers at the school as well as the hospital boiler, and from whom we shall obtain the required Certificates.

The costs are running very close to the estimates, and with the additional sums authorized for the extra work, I think we shall about break even. I will send a segregated statement of costs at an early date.

Speaking generally, the work is now on the last lap, and should be entirely completed within the next two or three weeks. I am arranging to be absent for a week or so to make the inspection of the St. Bruno's School, as instructed, and intend leaving for the north on May 9th.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Explanations of Above Items.

1. New Building, $66.68. The labour & materials shown under this heading together with the account of $197.32 previously rendered and paid for brings the cost of wiring the new addition to $264.00, exclusive of fixtures and lamps.

2. Fixtures, $74.31. This charge is for all the lighting fixtures required, exclusive of light bulbs.

3. Bells & Alarms, $50.15. The bell system and fire alarm signals had to largely changed, and extended. Two new fire gongs and one signal bell, with extra push buttons were supplied and installed.

4. Dining Room, $30.35. In removing walls and stairway to enlarge the Dining Room, the existing wiring concealed in said walls had to be run elsewhere and changes made.

5. Alterations, $18.16. At the request of the Rev. Principal a hall and store-room were incorporated in the ground floor plan of the new addition, which accounts for the labour and materials charged under this heading.

6. Change Switching in Dormitories, $9.77. The building of a new divisional partition across the existing girls' dormitory made it necessary to alter the circuit and switching.

7. Attic Lighting, $25.67. The attic over both the existing school and the new addition are used for storing clothing, etc., when not being used. This item covers the cost of conduit lighting, switches and outlets for the entire attic.

8. Fire Escapes, $14.89. Formerly open wiring carried light to fire escape platforms. This is contrary to the Electric Code, and has been replaced with conduit wiring.

9. Pressure Tank, $20.68. We found the pressure running wild in this tank. Both the obsolete safety valve and the electric cut out were not functioning, with danger to the system. The plumber installed a new safety valve; and the item under this heading covers the cost of a dependable automatic pressure switch and connections.
Explanations of Electric Account cont'd.

10. Lamps (Electric), $21.09. This item covers the cost of the 46 lamps required, of varying strength, as requested.

11. Basement Alterations, $8.21. It became necessary to change the switching in the existing basement, and provide an extra switch.

12. West Porch, $4.08. The cost of a light extension to this porch.

13. Rear Entrances, $11.27. The two rear entrances were formerly supplied with drop lights from open wiring brought from circuits in the main building. These have been replaced with conduit wiring in compliance with the Code.

14. The former east furnace room has been converted into a drying room, with a doorway cut through from the adjoining laundry. This item covers the cost of providing this new room with suitable lighting, at a cost of $7.23.

15. Laundry, $9.63. The wiring in the laundry has been extended, and conduit outlets brought to the laundry machines. This outlay makes the operation of the laundry both safer and more convenient.

Sir:

I beg to request that $500.00 additional advance be forwarded to this office, to pay for labour in connection with the building operations at the Morley Indian Residential School.

I may say I received the $500.00 asked for in my letter of the 9th instant, and as stated in that letter, I was of the opinion that amount would complete the job. Dr. McGill

Dear Dr. McGill:

We wish to very respectfully call your attention again to a suggestion we made to you and to your department some few months ago, in regard to an automatic stoker for your new school at Morley.

We have gone into the matter very thoroughly with your Mr. Christensen and Mr. Phalen, and they are both very well impressed with the stoker we are selling, and they indicated to us that if a favorable suggestion came from the Indian Department, that they would be very glad to confirm this suggestion.

I have in the previous letters pointed out to you the advantages to be gained from the use of this stoker, and I am quite sure that the proposition would meet with your entire approval if you fully realize the net value to this institution at Morley.

I shall be pleased indeed if you will write both Mr. Phalen and Mr. Christensen and get their comments on the advisability of installing this stoker.

We shall appreciate very much your usual prompt attention to this matter, and remain

Yours very sincerely,

O.H. Patrick,
president.

Sir:

Re- New Addition to Morley Indian School.

Your letter of recent date, addressed to Dr. W.B. Murray, Indian Agent, in reply to his telegram of the 11th instant, was duly received, and it was noted that no further funds will be available until an Order-in-Council is passed, for school construction.

The work on this job is completed with the exception of two or three more days' painting, and only the painter is still on the pay-roll. He should finish on the 20th, on which date I shall return to Morley for a day in order to complete the pay-roll and check up on the final work. My time ended on the 15th inst.

About $500.00 is owing to the workmen, for the last 3 weeks' period, and when this sum is received Dr. Murray can distribute the cheques as called for on the completed pay-roll. I have had the workmen sign the pay-sheets in advance, before they left for their homes, so he will simply have to mail their cheques to them.

On the completion of the painting I shall prepare and forward a full segregation of the costs on this work.

I am now available for other employment, and I trust it may soon be my privilege to be of further service to the Department.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

E.Gardner-Smith.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that an attempt was made last night and again this morning to set fire to the Indian School here, by a school-boy, Jock Simson, age 14.

This boy procured gasoline from Mr. Staley's garage, got matches from a boy who says he found them, whittled some shavings, and set them alight in the coal bin against the wall. He had a young boy help him, age 10, and not at all bright. Another boy about the same age acted as lookout. The fire was kindled last night and went out. This morning it was started again and burned through the wall boards of the coal bin, and if it had had another 15 minutes start, the building would have gone.

The local R.C.M.P. got the story from the boys this morning and in the presence of Mr. Staley, and myself, and we are all agreed that the best punishment as well as deterrent, would be for all three boys to be severely strapped, and the ringleader, Jock Simson, be sent to the Indian School at Edmonton until he reaches the age of discharge.

The three boys are being kept in confinement pending your approval.

Yours obediently,

W. B. MURRAY,
Indian Agent.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
CALGARY, Alta.
Sir:

I beg to attach hereto copy of a letter which I have just received from Dr. W. Barr Murray, Indian Agent at Morley, from which you will note that an attempt was made to set fire to the School. I was talking to Doctor Murray on the telephone this morning, and it now develops that another boy is implicated in the matter.

It is my intention to go up to Morley tomorrow afternoon, and on my return I shall report further to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA.
On the 2nd inst., the above named informed me that an attempt had been made to burn the Indian School at Morley and asked that an investigation be made.

Accompanied by the Indian Agent, Dr. W. Murray, a patrol left at once for the school and on arrival were taken to the scene of this fire. In the coal bin, on the southwest corner of the building there was found evidence that there had been a fire. In the corner of the coal bin was found some cut chips and a small piece of burnt paper. The wall in the corner of the bin had been badly burnt through inside wall burnt through and the sill badly charred. The fire had started to eat into wall and the draft had carried the flames upward toward the first floor. The fire was out at this time about 10:00 a.m.; watch was being kept in the event of any smouldering in the inside timbers.

This is the old part of the school and the wood wall comes below the ground. There is a window in the coal bin. The covering boards had been torn away and outside the window were tracks of running shoes. Near the windows on the ground were some more cut chips. These chips had been cut with a jack knife.

The amount of damage done was very small due to the prompt action taken by the staff in putting the fire out and about $2.00 worth of lumber will replace the damage done.

Mr. Stayley was asked if he had any idea who was responsible for setting the fire and he stated that a boy named Jock Simeon had admitted setting the fire. He had been assisted by another boy Paul Dixon.

Jock Simeon was questioned. He stated that he was 14 years old and that he had set this fire so that he could have to go to school. On the night of the fire he had attempted to start the fire but his match had not lit. He could not burn. When he got up in the morning he had taken two other boys with him. One of them had stayed outside the furnace room to see if any person came along so that they could escape to get away without being seen. Jock had kindled, poured the gasoline over it and given it to Paul Dixon who had lit the fire. Both boys escaped at once one by way of the window, the other had been taken off to make a draft, and then joined the Lefthand boy on his way up.
The time was about 7:30 when this fire was set. At 7:45 a.m., Mr. J. Hogarth, one of school staff, smelled smoke in the staff dining room and went to the basement thinking that the water heater was smoking. This is a very unusual thing and at that time he did not think anything unusual of the smoke. On his return the smell of smoke was much stronger and accompanied by Mr. Locke, another member of the school staff, they went to the basement again when they saw smoke and sparks coming from the No. 1 corner near the coal bin. Steps were at once taken to put out the fire and with their prompt action no further damage was done and the fire got no further along inside of the walls. The doors were not locked into any of these rooms and the pupils had free access to this part of the building.

Paul Dixon stated that he had assisted the Simeon boy in the morning to start this fire. Simeon had given him the matches to light the fire. Dixon's age is ten years and there is no doubt but that Simeon being an older boy was the leader of this party. The Left Hand boy acting as the Look Out had nothing to do with the setting of the fire but was only acting on the instructions of the older boy.

Both of the small boys connected with this are well spoken of by their teachers and as yet never mixed in any mischief of any serious nature.

The Simeon boy has a very low mental rating and is considered not very bright by his teachers. He is of a sullen manner and when reprimanded tends to sulk.

The Indian Agent pointed out that if this fire had started the night before it would have been very serious and no doubt if the school had burnt some of the children might have been burnt to death. This boy did not seem to consider this and stated so. Dr. Murray is recommending to the Indian Dept. that this boy be transferred to the Indian School at Edmonton. The other two boys will be given the cane for their part in the affair.

Dr. Murray and Mr. Stayley consider that sending this boy to Edmonton and having him attend the school at that point would be much better and have a more lasting effect on the boy than any other punishment. The school at Edmonton is a fireproof building and he will have no chance to repeat his offence. There is no doubt but this boy planned this fire and took much time to make his plan successful.

In the afternoon of yesterday's date, Oct. 1st, the parents of this boy were warned and a meeting was held at the Indian Agency where the whole matter was explained to them. This patrol was made by private car.

Further report will be submitted when the Dept. decide on the transfer of this boy to Edmonton.

UNLESS INVESTIGATION

The Insp. of Indian Agencies,
CALGARY.

Dear Mr. Christianson,

As a result of what transpired at your investigation Saturday into the series of efforts to set fire to the school I wonder if you would be willing to suggest to your Department the following:

That the punishment in the cases be as follows, that the boys concerned be given a severe strapping but that action be suspended on sending them away for this offence.

Sir:

I beg to attach hereto police reports on the attempted arson at the Morley Indian Residential School by some boys there. I am aware that the Department receive these police reports, but in case these have not been received as yet, I am forwarding them to you.

At the request of the Agent and the Indians I went up to Morley on Saturday afternoon and met the Band at the Agency, and the Indians themselves were very much worried over what had taken place and to explain it in the Indians' way they stated that they blamed themselves for this having happened as they had not trained their children properly before sending them to school, and during the time they were there, and that the boys would not have taken this action had they (the parents) been more strict with them. The Indians requested me to point out to the Department they did not want the boys sent away from the reserve to another school and that they would do everything in their power to see that the children behaved in future, and that they would talk to them and warn them. If anything of this nature were ever attempted again, the Indians were prepared to suffer the consequences, but they were quite confident it would not happen again. I am attaching hereto a letter from Mr. Staley, the Principal, who is of the same mind, and I concur with him in his opinion that the children should be let remain there. The Stony Indians are a very law-abiding lot, and as I have said before they feel the matter keenly, and if the boys are soundly strapped either by the Principal or the Parents in the presence of the Indian Agent, I feel this should suffice. I would ask that I be directed as soon as possible in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your 409-11 B of the 4th and 7th instant, with attached correspondence, relative to the attempt that was made by certain of the pupils of the Morley Indian Residential School to set fire to the building.

The Department considers that this is a very serious matter and that punishment should be administered to the boys who made the attempt to set fire to the building. It is noted the Principal recommends that the boys be given a severe whipping instead of having them placed in other institutions and that you concur in this action; also that you concur with him in his opinion that the boys be allowed to remain at the Morley School. It is noted, further, that the Principal is prepared to accept full responsibility for their future conduct.

The boys concerned in an attempt to set fire to the building should receive adequate punishment, which will serve as a deterrent to them and as an example to the other pupils, and this should be administered either by the Principal or the parents, in the presence of the Indian Agent. The Department will approve of their punishment, as recommended by the Principal and yourself; rather than having the boys concerned sent to a reform school. This action is taken in view of the wishes of the Indians of the Studen Band and also the fact that the Principal has accepted full responsibility for the future conduct of these boys. The punishment should be carried out at the earliest date and all pupils should be informed that any further attempt on the part of anyone to damage the building by fire or otherwise will be more severely punished by having the pupil responsible committed by a magistrate to a term in a reform school.

Your obedient servant,

PB CALGARY, ALTA., May 13th, 1936.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Indian Residential School at Morley. I must say I have very little to report on this institution, as when the new addition was put on the school last year it was repaired throughout, and is in first class shape in every way, well furnished and well kept throughout. The furniture and fixtures are well arranged and well taken care of. The machinery is all in good shape.

There were 75 children present at the time of my visit. I believe everyone was under the impression that with the addition to the school it would take care of approximately 100 pupils. This did not work out, and from personal observation I would say it actually only takes care of the overflow under the previous arrangement. In going over the school and discussing it with Mr. Staley, I believe he should only have from 60 to 62 children in this institution at any one time.

The children all looked well and there was no sickness in the school at that time.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The school has 40 head of cattle, 22 of which are cows, and they were milking 14 at the time of my visit, so the children are getting all the milk they require. They also make butter.

They have 9 horses at the school, 9 pigs and some chickens.

The Department are well aware that this school have no land of their own, and have to buy all the feed for their stock, &c. Some time ago I was advised by the Department that Lot 5 and part of Lot 7 in the Morleyville settlement that was used by the old MacDougall orphanage might be available. I sincerely hope it will be possible to procure these lots for the use of the school, which will give them just the amount of land they require for their farming operations.

Their gardening activities never meet with much success owing to frost during the summer.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Indian Residential School at Morley. I must say I have very little to report on this institution, as when the new addition was put on the school last year it was repaired throughout, and is in first class shape in every way, well furnished and well kept throughout. There were 75 children present at the time of my visit. I believe everyone was under the impression that with the addition to the school it would take care of approximately 100 pupils. This did not work out, and from personal observation I would say it actually only takes care of the overflow under the previous arrangement. In going over the school and discussing it with Mr. Staley, I believe he should only have from 80 to 82 children in this institution at any one time.

The children all looked well and there was no sickness in the school at that time.

Gentlemen:

With reference to the pumping system at the Morley Indian School, we find that there are several reasons for this pump not being able to furnish sufficient water for the school, as follows:

1st:- The cylinder valves on this pump are not in good order and the sand point also is very likely clogged, which condition will reduce the quantity of water to some degree.

2nd:- We know that there is some sand trouble in the well, and it is possible that it will require cleaning out. We cannot, however, say definitely that this is so until the pump is removed and the well examined.

3rd:- We find that what we consider to be the main cause is, that the school has been enlarged considerably, also that a modern Laundry has been installed; so that the water requirements are very much more than the present pump is able to handle, as this is only a small outfit which is used for ordinary residence purposes. The pressure tank is, however, of good size—4' by 16'.

In view of the above conditions, we consider and recommend that this well should be examined, and if found to have an accumulation of sand or silt that it be removed, and then a pump of much larger capacity be installed. We are pleased to quote you as follows:

We offer to remove the cylinder and piping from the well and find if the well requires to be cleaned, for the sum of $25.00 (twenty-five dollars).
Sir:

I beg to inform you that the Morley School have been having some difficulty with a shortage of water, and it appears that the present equipment for pumping, and the cylinder that is in the well, are simply too small for the quantity of water now used by the School since the addition was built. I might say for the information of the Department that the well is only 40 feet deep, and apparently there is nothing wrong in the well itself, but the pumping outfit, as I have said before, is too small for the amount of water it is called upon to handle.

Sir:

I have been informed by Rev. E. J. Staley, principal of the Residential School, that there is almost no water available in the school well. This he considers is due to failure of the source of supply rather than a need of cleaning.

The well is drilled down to shale and as the depth of the shale is not known, further drilling is not considered feasible. The C.P.R. have an electric pump about 500 yards from the school used to pump water from the river to their tank at the station. Report
on
Water Situation at Indian Residential School
Morley, Alberta.

1. Purpose of Report.

A letter dated July 28, 1936, Ottawa file 41167-W, was received from the Director requesting that an investigation be made of the domestic water situation at the above-named school and that an estimate be made of the cost of rehabilitating the water supply plant.

This office was afterwards informed by the Inspector of Indian Agencies that an amount of $75 had been appropriated for repairing the well machinery and cleaning out the well. It was intimated that Mr. R.W. Snyder of Lepper & Co., Plumbers, was to visit the school and make repairs. Consequently, the writer proceeded to Morley on August 4 to survey the situation alone. The main visit was made on August 10 with Mr. Snyder when temporary rehabilitation was made.

2. Causes of the trouble.

The working head had to be disassembled and the pipes, cylinder and sand point removed. The cause of trouble was at first very obscure. Decisions had to be made on the spot as to possible remedies. It was decided to install a 3" cylinder. The leather washers were partially worn and leaked badly. The sand point screen holes were partially filled with oil. The six-inch conical point of the sand point had been driven into the shale. None of these difficulties, however, explained the total inability of the pump to raise practically any water, even when working 24 hours per day. It might be mentioned that on August 4 the writer caused the pump to be activated for four hours. As far as could be noted very little water was delivered to the tank, although the pump head leaked water to the floor at every stroke. The principal stated that it would be absolutely impossible to open the school until the water supply was assured. This decision was concurred in fully by the writer. The pump had been activated for 24 hours per day in order to obtain a very limited amount of water for limited purposes.

However, after a full examination of the equipment (the 2½" cylinder was scored) the well was bailed out. It was found that during the last few years 10 gallons of oil had entered the pipe from the working head. Seven feet of pipe is under water level and probably only a foot or so of the sand point was in water. Although this seemed to be the primary cause of lack of supply, it was considered advisable to leave the 3" cylinder in the well. The question of general inability of the plant to supply sufficient water will be dealt with at a later point in this report. The actual water supply appears to be unlimited.
3. Temporary Removal of Cause of Trouble.

As mentioned above a new 3" cylinder was installed under the 2½" pipe. The sand point was removed as it was considered that there is no sand present now to interfere with the working of the pump. The oil was entirely removed from the pipe. The working head was replaced, together with the pipe and valves, and the whole reconnected with the pressure tank.

The pump was started, and in three hours the tank was pumped from a state of emptiness to full capacity (55 pounds pressure). The total amount pumped in amounted to about 900 gallons, or about 300 gallons per hour.

4. Ultimate Necessary Activities.

(a) Present Physical conditions

Although the pump was working well after repair, it does not follow that the difficulties are overcome. This plant (working head and drop portion) was repaired during the winter. Frequent repairs have been and will be necessary. The fact is that the plant is entirely inadequate to provide the requirements of the present capacity of the school. Too much stress cannot be put on this statement. The ¾ h.p. motor is undoubtedly doing more work than it should do. The working head is entirely too small to provide sufficient water. It will surely again break down due to overwork. Although it may last a short while in its present condition, the whole plant should be renovated, as breakdowns may occur at crucial times, such as fire, when the school is full. This well is the only water supply available.

(b) Requirements of the School.

The population of the school, and Principal's house, together amount to about 100 people. A laundry, which is in use every day, has been added lately, together with a 40% or 50% addition to the main building. At a modest requirement of 30 gallons per capita per day the school should use at least 3000 gallons per day for domestic purposes, with some addition for lawn watering etc. A fair total estimate of total requirements would be 3500 gallons. Even this amount is less than that estimated for certain other schools of similar population, there being no stock to water.

(c) Present Plant.

The present plant consists of a Fairbanks-Morse enclosed working-head about 18" by 12" activated by a ¾ h.p. motor, installed 5 or 6 years ago. This working-head, No.9, is not manufactured now. The rated capacity is 275 gallons per hour, although it was apparently increased to 300 gallons by the 3" cylinder on August 10.
At least 12 hours continuous pumping is required at present for a day's supply. This is too long. The time occupied should not be for more than 4 or 5 hours. The present rate is 50 strokes per minute.

The pressure tank is 16' by 4' horizontal type. At full capacity (34½ inches at 57 pound pressure) it holds about 950 gallons. Thus it needs to be filled four times per day to provide for requirements.

It seems evident that another tank should be provided. The lean-to building, with 3' of concrete basement and 5' of frame, is 20' by 11½' inside measurement with the tank at one side and the pump near the centre. It would be necessary to extend the building westward about 8' for installation of a second tank. The concrete wall, 3' high, could be left intact except for a door. The roof would be extended at a flatter angle than at present.

(d) Water Supply for Principal's House.

The house occupied by Rev. Mr. Staley, Principal, is about 600 feet from the school. The water supply for the house is provided by means of barrels filled at the school and carried by team to the house. This is obviously a laborious method. A pipe could be laid from the school to the house and proper plumbing facilities installed. An alternative plan would be the sinking of a well at the house and installation of a pumping system.

A rough estimate of cost of taking water by pipeline to house, including cost of pipe, would be $600 exclusive of plumbing. This is considered to be expensive. The most economical method is to excavate a well (drillers dislike drilling in gravel) within three or four feet of the house basement. A small extension 6' square could be constructed from the basement, directly connected with it, and the machinery installed therein. The soil consists of coarse gravel for over 20 feet depth.

5. Estimate of Cost of Plant Extension.

| Item                                                                 | Cost   |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------|--------|
| 1 Pressure Tank 5/16 inch shell, 2" openings, 1250 gallons, 3000 pounds with pipe, valves etc., | 550.00 |
| 1 working-head and motor, capacity 800 gallons per hour             | 350.00 |
| Extension of housing building from 21' by 11' to 21' by 18'          | 300.00 |
| Provision for water supply at house by well                         |        |
| (a) well machinery                                                  | 300.00 |
| (b) excavation of 4' square well                                     | 100.00 |
| (c) housing                                                         | 100.00 |

Total: $1,700.00
The water system of the school has gradually been repaired because of inadequacy of the water supply plant as the school was enlarged, until the limit is passed. Consequently provision should be made for a real extension as described above.

6. The Pumping Plant at the Agent's House.

Dr. Murray can obtain only a small amount of water at each pumping. Apparently the syphon at the well leaks as he can only lower the well to the outlet pipe. This pipe is upright from near the bottom of the well for 2 feet. It then bends westward and horizontally to flow downhill to the house. This, again, needs repair, as only a few gallons can be pumped at a time.

7. R.C.M. Police Barracks.

The writer's attention was called by the Agent, Dr. Murray, to the condition of the well at the bungalow which serves as residence and barracks for the Mounted Police.

This well, 4' square, is excavated underneath the kitchen basement. It is concreted for 10 feet. The base of the concrete rests on shale. The portion of shale immediately below the concrete wall was left intact, but that within and below the concrete wall was excavated in the form of a seepage cavity in the shape of a bowl with a capacity of 20 or 25 gallons.

A good pumping plant is installed over the well on the basement floor. The water appears and disappears, apparently being influenced by the height of the Bow river, although not likely. An expenditure of $50 would increase the capacity of the cavity to a sufficient amount to provide water supply for the household. It could be deepened from a maximum depth of less than 2½' in the bowl, to say 4' by 4', i.e., a square cavity. The concrete walls could be extended downward by an orthodox method.

8. Recommendations.

(a) Provision in the 1937 estimates for a complete renovation of the Water Supply at the School ........................................... $1200.00

(b) A well or a pipe line at the Principal's house including well machinery and extension to basement but excluding plumbing fixtures .................. 500.00

15% for contingencies .................................. 255.00

Total for (a) and (b) & contingencies ............... $1955.00
(c) Further excavation of well at Police residence and barracks .................................. $50.00

The last estimate is not to be included in the Indian Department estimates.

9. Plans.

A sketch plan of the layout of buildings accompanies this report under separate cover. In addition, comparative levels were also obtained, and are shown in the form of an elevation on the plan. If it be decided to go ahead with this work, more detailed plans can be prepared in preparation for next year.

Sir:

With reference to your No. 119-15 of the 25th ultimo re root house and new pumping unit at the Morley Indian Residential School, I discussed the matter with Mr. M. Christienson when he was here, and I had decided to go into the matter fully with him and Mr. E. J. Staley, the principal, when we visited the reserve on the 13th ultimo, but did not do so as Mr. Staley was away on vacation at the time of our visit. Since the above date I have been away with Mr. Christienson visiting agencies, and I also made a trip to Lesser Slave Lake Agency while in the North, returning home last Sunday evening. Hence the reason for the matter not being attended to sooner.

On Monday last I phoned Dr. W. B. Murray, the Agent, suggesting that Rev. Staley begin the work of cleaning the old root cellar pit, which I understand is to be used again for the new root house. I later phoned Mr. Staley, asking him to prepare a list of material required, telling him I intended going to Morley to discuss the matter with him. This afternoon he called at this office with Mr. W. T. Scott, of Calgary, whom he wishes to engage to supervise the work. Mr. Scott had with him a plan of a timber (not concrete) root house, 20' x 30' x 10', the cost of which would be approximately $600.00 -- $525.00 for material and $75.00 for labour.

I pointed out that the figure submitted to the Department was $500.00 only, and was informed that when this amount was placed in the Estimates last summer, no list of material, cost of same, or cost of labour, had been prepared; that the figure given was approximate, or in other words a "guess."

As regards the purchase of material, Mr. Staley says there are two sawmills in the vicinity,--one on the reserve, operated by a Mr. Darnelle, the other some six miles from the School, the owner's name he did not remember.--He tells me the price of materials at these mills is much lower than at the lumber yards in Calgary.

The Secretary,

OTTAWA.
Mr. Staley now asks that authority be given him to expend $500.00 to build a root house, and that he be authorized to engage Mr. W. T. Scott to supervise the work, other labour to be done by the school staff. He will submit certified vouchers for material purchased; also for Mr. Scott's wages.

I recommend that the request be granted and would ask that I be advised by telegram so that the work may be started at once, as the weather is uncertain in the Morley district.

Re new pumping unit for the school: I have been trying to contact Mr. R. W. Snyder of Calgary, but have been unable to do so yet, as he has been out of the city for some time. On Monday I called at his home and was told he was expected home on Sunday next. I asked that he call on my early next week, when I will discuss the matter with him, and ask him to give me a quotation, which I will forward to the Department immediately.

Your obedient servant,

The total head against which a pump is operating is figured by adding the distance in feet from the position of the pump head to the lowest water level in the well, to the tank pressure which can be reduced from pounds pressure to feet head by multiplying the maximum pounds pressure in the tank by 2.3. Any vertical height from the pump head to the tank should also be added. Horizontal suction and discharge lines within reason do not add materially to the head.

A complete deep well Hydro pneumatic or pressure system includes the following—

Deep well working head for above-ground or underground discharge—motor—belt—automatic pressure controller—tank—gauge glass and mountings—pressure pipe—check valve—drain cock for tank—discharge pipe between pump head and tank—gate valve—horizontal check valve—union—tee for controller—tee for relief valve—necessary nipples and elbows—suction pipe—pump rod—cylinder—foot valve and strainer.

The cylinder is a very important part of any deep-well outfit, and only the best brass body and lined cylinders are recommended for this purpose. McDougall cylinders have a reputation for giving real service on all depths of wells, and can be supplied in all sizes and lengths as listed in our catalogue and price list.

In selecting the proper deep-well pumping equipment for any installation, a number of necessary points must be considered—i.e., the amount of water required per hour or day—the depth of the well—the inside diameter of the casing if a drilled well—power available, whether electric motor or steam—consider the distance from the surface of the ground to the lowest water level, and whether pressure or gravity tank system is desired.

Dear Sir:

In view of the fact that a substantial balance remains out of the $600.00 allowed us for the building of a root cellar, would you be good enough to ask the Department if it would be possible for us to use this unexpended balance for the purchase of rough lumber with which to erect a shelter shed for the cattle at the School.

The weather here is such that on a great many days in the winter time the cattle would benefit greatly by being out of doors, but owing to the high winds that usually prevail, it is quite impossible to turn them out. The shed would be used then for shelter for the milk cows, and would serve a further purpose of providing the necessary accommodation at nights for the range cattle which we are compelled to feed during the winter. We would also use it for a weaning shed for the calves at various times of the year.

Your full consideration of this matter is requested.

Yours very truly,

(signed) C. J. Staley.

Dear Dr. Murray,

I am sorry to inform you that the buildings on the school lease at the orphanage property were destroyed by fire yesterday afternoon. The buildings while of no great value were useful as winter shelter for the cattle. The fire which was discovered about two o'clock by men having on the place burned fiercely and was soon out of control. We were fortunate enough to save large stacks of rye 160 yds. away although there is still some danger and will be for some considerable time because the fire is still burning in large manure piles. I have as yet no explanation to offer as to the cause of the fire.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

E. J. Staley
Stony Agency.

Morley, Alta. July 25th 1938.

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr Staley, copy of which is enclosed herewith, in which he reports the loss of some of the buildings on the orphanage property, from fire.

It would appear that the fire started up after lunch, in the old stable where the men had been eating their lunch & no doubt was caused by a carelessly thrown down match or cigarette stub & everything being so very dry & no water available there was no chance to save the building & they did very well indeed to save about thirty five tons of rye hay which was stacked near by.

The building was of no great value & was about ready to fall down anyhow.

Mr Staley has not mentioned possible replacement & I have not either & until he does I think we might let it go at that.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Sir:—

You will recall previous correspondence about the new pump installed at the School, and that it was recommended by the dealers that a larger outlet from the pump to pressure tank was necessary.

At present there is a plumber overhauling the heating system at the school, and he drew my attention to damage being done to the pump by the present outlet line being too small. He quoted a price of $25 to correct the situation, and I have ordered the work done as emergent. The price previously quoted by Anderson of Calgary for the same job was $45. I trust you will approve my action.

Yours obediently,

Calgary, Sept. 24th, 1938.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter received from Dr. W. H. Murray, Indian Agent, Morley:

The new pump mentioned was installed last October: (Reference Dept. letter No. 119-1-5 of Oct. 7, 1937 and my No. 409-11A. of the 26th idem).

When Mr. Anderson installed the pump, his agreement was to install a new pump, lower pipe, and new cylinder. In other words, everything new from the pump-head downward. It is now found that the discharge pipe, from the pump-head to the pressure tank, is of a smaller size. Therefore the water is forced into the pressure tank, and this causes vibrations and considerable noise, and is also detrimental to the pump gears, &c.

By changing the outlet or discharge pipe for a larger one, the extra pressure, vibrations and noise will, we are told, be eliminated. This is what Doctor Murray has ordered done. I trust his action will be approved and the voucher paid when submitted to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

C. Pant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

We now come to invoice #7. In the amount of $30.02 as you will see if you check the items on invoice just about every tap was leaking at the school as we used 36 washers in leaky taps alone, you will also notice it was necessary for us to install two new ball cocks in the toilet tanks, as they were completely worn out, with result the water was running straight thru them.

There was also a wash basin almost off the wall that had to be replaced and properly installed, flush balls in 2 instances were leaking badly and with conditions such as described it just meant that water pump was going full blast all the time in order to keep up with the wastage.

Referring to invoice #6, in the amount of $11.55 for cleaning boiler at the Hospital, this was necessary due to the fact that the oil burner had not been functioning proper for some time with the result that a great deal of carbon, was deposited all thru the boiler and it certainly is only good business at any time to thoroughly clean out the boiler in the fall preparatory for winter's use, more especially in the case of a Hospital where very serious results could happen in the event of a boiler failure during the cold weather.

We trust the above explanation will clear up any question of why this expense was necessary in all cases, and we will look forward to receiving the departments, check at their earliest opportunity as I can assure you we have got some heavy commitments to make, and payment, of account would be very much appreciated at this time.

Dear Sir:

Further to our conversation, over the telephone re invoices rendered as of Aug. 31st. 1938, for repairs to Plumbing and Heating boiler etc.

Taking the invoices in rotation viz To Cleaning and Flushing out boilers total cost. $33.80.

Invoice #2.
If you will recall this was the original job that we were called on to do, and it certainly proved very necessary, as we found the boiler very dirty indeed and if same had not been attended to at the time there is a grave doubt in the writers mind whether you would have got thru the winter without a breakdown, it was whilst we were cleaning and inspecting the boiler in question that we found it was absolutely necessary in the interest of safety alone to replace the defective return lines of the heating plant to the boiler as in some instances the nipples were eaten clear thru with rust, and if they had not been replaced when they were, the certainly would have emptied the boiler where either an explosion or a burnt out boiler would have been the result. This repair covered invoice #4.

Invoice #3.
Covers the renewing of circulating pipes from new pump that was installed last year. This was was necessary for this reason. There is a 2" discharge from pump to tank, but when pump was installed for some unknown reason the 2" discharge was bushed down to 1 1/4", with this result pump was gradually pounding itself to pieces, and it would only be a matter of time before it would have been a wreck and would have to be replaced and we consider that this expense of $30.61

Sir:-

I duly received your letter of November 26th, File No. 409-11A, & immediately got in touch with Messrs. Shrubshall & Coy asking them to furnish me with a report on the work done by them at the school & the reason for it's being done.

I have now received a report from Mr. Shrubshall setting forth the reasons for the work being done, copy of which report is submitted herewith.

I might say that the contents of your letter of August 16th were conveyed to Mr. Staley, the principal of the school & he retained the services of Mr. Shrubshall to do the work & having him on the ground, had him do the other work.

In doing this Mr. Staley had in mind the lateness of the date & the immediate prospect of the children being back in residence & the absolute necessity of having the work done immediately. The necessity of having the work done during the holiday season had been outlined in correspondence in the Spring & the request that it be done was based on an inspection of the equipment by plumbing & heating experts. Mr. Staley considered that by having it done while the men were on the ground, he was saving the Department a much greater outlay at a not very distant date & without looking over the equipment, one could not judge how very necessary it was that the work be done.

On the face of it, it looks as though the authority of the Department had been overstepped to a considerable extent, but this was done not solely to buck authority, but with a view to having something done, which was in the best interests of the Department.

I trust that my explanation as above may be accepted.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter No. 119-1-5 dated the 23rd ultimo, re exceeding the amount of $50.00 authorized for checking the boiler and heating plant at the Morley Indian Residential School.

Your letter was received here during my absence on a visit to the Lesser Slave Lake Agency, and Miss P. Blanchfield immediately wrote Dr. W. B. Murray, Indian Agent, asking him for an explanation. I am attaching hereto copy of his reply, with enclosure.

Doctor Murray called at this office yesterday, when I discussed the matter with him.

The only reason he gave for exceeding the amount allowed, was that Mr. Shrubsall had found that the repairs were urgently needed and Rev. Mr. Staley, the principal, was most anxious to have them done before school re-opened. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 119-1-5, Dec. 22, re over-expenditure on repairs to the heating plant at the school.

A full explanation has been forwarded through the Inspector's office, accompanied by a letter from the plumber giving a technical explanation to show the urgency of the work. I expect these have reached the Department by this time.

Mr. Shrubsall came out and cleaned the boilers which was the job that I knew had to be done. He then looked over the whole plant and showed me valves, nipples, etc., which were worn out and in urgent need of replacing. On looking at the new well pump, he showed me that it would soon be ruined unless the outlet pipe were enlarged. There is no one in the community who knows anything about heating systems and I had to follow my judgment based on the technical information he had given me. He states in his letter that major breakdowns might have occurred if these repairs had not been effected. If that had occurred after my having been warned by a heating expert, I likely would be held responsible. The children were due to come into school thereby increasing the work of heating system and plumbing, not leaving sufficient time to communicate with the Department, so I ordered the work performed; the sole purpose being to prevent a greater expense.

This information should have gone with the voucher but it inadvertently got into the mail before an explanatory letter was written.

I further beg to state that care and supervision were exercised by both Mr. Staley and myself and there was no lack of interest or of checking on my part while the work was proceeding. I trust that Mr. Shrubsall's letter will show the urgent nature of the work, and that its being performed was to the best interests of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

On checking over Heating System at Morley School, I have found the following defects.

(1) Discharge from pump in to equalizer pipes is tapped into pipe instead of the proper fittings; this causes leaks as there is not thread enough in 3" pipe to hold same.

This can be remedied by installing two 3" x 1½" tees; Two 3" flange unions, four 3" nipples and necessary 1½" nipples on discharge from pump.

(2) On return header at back of boilers, there are no valves, and water does not equalize in boilers as one glass shows as much as 4" more than the other.

This can be overcome by putting in two 2" gate valves on return and twinning boilers with necessary unions and fittings. This connection is necessary as at present one boiler is getting more water than other from condensate pump. This also will provide the use of one boiler and an even water line.

(3) The main feed header valve requires gland packing as they show evidence of leaks.

(4) Check valves on discharge line from pump to boiler to be ground in on seat.

(5) Cleanout plugs in boilers are cast iron, brass plugs should be used as they are easily removed for cleaning purposes and do not rust.

Sir:

Reference your radiogram of the 25th ultimo re repairs required for electric pump at the Morley Indian Residential School, Stony Agency, I beg to advise that in the absence of Mr. Schmidt, I got in touch with Dr. W. Barr Murray, the Indian Agent, who suggested that I ask Mr. P. Kennedy, Plumber, Calgary, to go to Morley to fix this pump. I contacted Mr. Kennedy, who went to Morley to look over the pump to see what repairs and material were required.

Mr. Kennedy called at this office today and informed me that the cost of the job would be $94.00, for labour and material, including 40 feet of 3-inch pipe, 40 feet of 58 wood pump rod, 3-inch cylinder, material for air cushion, &c. He stated that the pump is at present "hammering itself to pieces" and that something should be done at once, but he preferred that I inform the department of the cost before he proceeded with the work. I am sending this letter by air mail, and beg to ask for a reply by radio so that there need be no delay in getting this pump in good working order.

Sir:

I beg to report that it has been necessary to incur two bills for urgent repairs to plumbing.

The first was in my house when a water pipe plugged up with rust and sediment stopping the flow; also a pipe rusted through at the thread. P. Kennedy was called and made the repair.

The second accident was at the school. A swing check valve between the pump and pressure tank gave way allowing water to run back through the pump and flood the floor. I purchased a new check valve and new washers and the school staff did the work.

I trust my actions will be approved.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Attached herewith please find six separate requisitions for the Morley Indian Residential School.

1. This requisition is asking for beds, mattresses, and blankets. These are really necessary in order to keep up the equipment.

2. Requisition for 1000 ft. No.1 Edge Grain Flooring. This is really required for patching worn places in the various dormitories and other rooms in the Residential School building. I inspected these floors recently and recommend this expenditure.

3. Requisition for paint and shingle stain. I recommend that this paint be purchased in order to preserve the roofs and interior woodwork.

4. Requisition for materials to build an additional mink house, capable of housing 150 mink. The raising of mink has been very successful and the profits are substantial. The school boys are very enthusiastic with this venture and I recommend this material be furnished.

5. Requisition asking for repairs to plumbing and toilets, and a new toilet bowl, also for the cleaning and blowing out of boilers. A complete check and necessary repairs required for the steam-heating equipment. The boilers should yearly be blown and cleaned out each year. This work has not been done for three years. I recommend this be done as early as possible in order that we may avoid more costly repairs at a later date.

6. Requisition asking for Battleship linoleum to cover school dining-room floor. If funds are available I would like to have this done but the five previous items are more important, and this could probably wait for another year.

Your obedient servant,

J.M.A. Ireland,
Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 7th wherein you request a receipted railway expense bill for $3.71 covering the freight upon a shipment to the Morley Indian Residential School, ordered upon your purchase #5266 of August 13th.

Please be advised that it is absolutely impossible for us to supply you with a receipted railway expense bill covering this amount of freight, as the amount of tax and freight are part and parcel of our quotation upon your requisition #54776, file 15/3. The freight is based upon inclusion in carload lots from our Winnipeg factory to our Calgary selling branch, and reshipment by local freight from Calgary to Morley.

From the above you will recognize that we could not possibly have a freight bill from Winnipeg to Morley, and in any event, the freight would be extremely higher if merchandise was shipped L.C.L. from Winnipeg to Morley.

As your request for quotation called for f.o.b. Morley prices, instead of quoting you a straight price, which we would have done had it been a matter of local freight to be added, we showed in our quotation the prices of the articles, the tax and the freight as three separate items.

We trust that with this information before you you will be able to pass our invoices for payment.

Yours very truly,

Mr Iredale,
Indian Agent,
Morley, Alberta.

Dear Mr Iredale,

I wish to thank you for the very prompt attention given to our request for aid in the serious difficulties that arose by reason of the recent breakdown in our electrical system at the school. I am sorry the case was such as to need the immediate attention of an electrician and the time could not be spared to meet the request to the department in the usual way.

The situation revealed much more serious difficulties than we had imagined and involved a large amount of rewiring in the old part of the building. In fact, such was the condition of wiring that we were very lucky to have escaped from much more dangerous situations. Prior to the rebuilding, five years ago, the wiring had carried much too heavy loads and this was the real cause of the recent breakdown.

I can assure you that the prompt relief that we got from a very dangerous situation was greatly appreciated.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Residential School
United Church of Canada
Rev. E.J. Stalet, Principal

Morley, Alta.
January 4, 1940
Stony Indian Agency.
Morley, Alberta.
6th January, 1941

Sir:

In connection with attached Voucher No. 216 in favour of Lloyd Orr Electric, Calgary, for $82.91, for electrical repairs and labour at the Morley Residential School.

I would point out that this was very urgent. I was called over to the School on the morning of the 26th December, as they had a breakdown in the power at the School residence. Mr. Staley informed me that Lloyd Orr Electric had done the installation of the electric system. I therefore got this man on the phone and asked him to come out and fix up the trouble, as myself and the School Staff were unable to locate the reason for the breakdown. He therefore came out, and discovered that we had been in serious danger of having a fire, as a lot of the old wiring was completely burnt out, and this job turned out to be more costly than we had expected. However this job should be good for many years to come.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith six requisitions for materials and labour for the Morley Indian Residential School, prepared by Rev. E.J. Staley, the Principal, and forwarded here by Mr. J.N.R. Iredale, the Acting Indian Agent. I am changing the order of preference as follows:

1. Requisition No. 2 is for enlarging the septic tank. This is very, very much needed: The present tank is too small. (Ref. my reports on this School, dated Feb. 2nd and Dec. 2nd, 1939, Pages 7 and 6, respectively). I would ask that this matter be given immediate consideration, and the work completed before the reopening of the School in September, next.

2. Requisition No. 3: I would ask that $150.00 be allowed for plumbing repairs.

3. Requisition No. 5: Both the Binder and Hay Rake will be required this Summer. I recommend that these items be allowed.

Re Requisition No. 1, for paint - both outside and inside:
Re-painting the outside, and decorating the interior would, of course, brighten things considerably. Owing to War conditions, I am not recommending same. The Department are aware that we have cancelled a certain amount of outside painting of the Agency buildings: (Ref. Dept. No. 21-119 of June 6th, 1941). The Agency and School buildings are only a few rods apart, and both are seen from the main (tourist) highway; if any exterior painting is done, both sets of buildings should be touched up.

Requisition No. 4 is for a shed to be built on what is referred to as the Orphanage Ranch; Viz., lands taken over by the School (Church) for stock growing purposes. (See Dept. No. 119-1-9 dated Dec. 17th, 1935; also No. 119-1-14 dated May 14th, 1937, and Jan. 29th, 1938). The School grow a few acres of green feed and keep their main herd of cattle on this place, both in Summer and Winter. Owing to War conditions, I am not prepared to recommend this, and I am wondering whether the Department should be asked to pay for improvements on this farm.

Requisition No. 6 is for 500 feet of two-inch pipe, to convey water to the hogs: This is, without a doubt, a great labour-saving device; however, I consider the work can be carried on as in the past, and the saving of the cost of the material go towards War services.

Re flooring asked for on Requisition No. 5: This is asked for to renew the flooring in the dormitories. These floors are showing signs of wear, and will have to be renewed before long. If the Department find that they cannot grant the full amount, I would suggest that say half of it be given this year.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Sir:

Re your letter, file 409-11A, dated July 26th 1941, regarding the repairs for the septic tank at the Morley Residential School.

After receiving your letter, Mr. Staley got Mr. Lepper of the F.H. Lepper Co. of Calgary, to come out and give an estimate on the work required. With the result, Mr. Lepper said the septic tank did not require to be enlarged, and that the whole trouble was caused by the laundry water going directly into the first compartment of the septic tank. As this liquid contained so much soap, lye, and other bleaching compounds etc., it absolutely killed or destroyed bacterial action, which would ordinarily take place in the first compartment of the septic tank, with the result that the tank was always plugging up with solids, and would not syphon into the second and third compartments.

Therefore, the only way to remedy the condition, would be to re-construct the drains from the Laundry and run the drainage direct from the Laundry to the third compartment of the septic tank. This would entail a considerable amount of labour, as they would have to dig a trench about four or five feet deep, and about one hundred feet long. They would also have to take up part of the Laundry floor (concrete) and break through the concrete foundation in order to change the direction of the drains. The Lepper Co. have agreed to do the work and furnish the material required, for the sum of $250.00.

Regarding the other plumbing work required. This is asked for, to install an eight foot double wash sink in the girls wash room. The Lepper Co. have one of these on hand, which they have had for some time, and the cost of the material is $165.00. In view of the fact that they have had to keep this wash sink for years, before they had a call for it, they offer to instal this at the Morley Residential School, Material and Labour, for the sum of $150.00.

The above offer would appear to me, to be very reasonable, and the work is very necessary, and should be done immediately, if possible before school re-opens. However, I would mention that this Company's name does not appear on the approved list.

For your consideration, please.

Your obedient servant,

J.M.R. Redden
Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

The attached invoices from Lepper and Co., are of course a representation of bills originally forwarded last October.

Most of the work involved came about by reason of emergent repairs that had to be affected at the school. Among other things the hot water system broke down completely and it was found that quite apart from repairs being needed to the jacket heater, that certain lines and most of the taps were completely worn out and incapable of being repaired. Accordingly repairs to this phase of our hot water supply were affected. This involved a great deal of the material on invoice including new flume pipes from the jacket heater. While dealing with the hot water system repairs were affected to the toilets through the buildings and in addition several leaky valves on the heating system were either repaired or replaced.

The appendix shows a crane check valve that had to be secured and fitted in the pipe line leading from the pump to the water storage tank. The old valve was worn out and was allowing the water to leak back into the well.

The bill as a whole can be certified as correct and came about because after twenty years of use the break down of one portion necessarily resulted in trouble in other directions.

Lepper & Company, Calgary.

This account is for plumbing work done by the above named firm at the Morley Indian Residential School building during the month of October, 1944.

Sometime early in October, 1944 Mr. Staley notified me that he was having some trouble with the hot water system and must have some immediate repairs done.

As this appeared to be an emergency he said he would have to get a plumber out right away. In this I concurred.

At that time I was under the impression that it not going to be a very big or expensive job. I was not notified by Mr. Staley that it had become necessary to do so much additional work.

The first I knew about this invoice was about two months ago when I received an "Account Rendered" statement from the plumbing company and upon making enquiries from Mr. Staley he said he had received the invoice last October and had brought it over to the Agency Office, but I am sure that it was never received by this office.

However, I got in touch with Lepper & Co. and asked them to re-submit their account and when I received their statement I was considerably surprised at so much work being done without the Agency approval. So much so, that I requested Mr. Staley to write a letter of explanation a copy of which is attached herewith.

I checked over the work and it appears to have been done alright. I notice one item in the account for "meals $6.60." I don't think this item should be allowed.

J.N.H. Iredale,

Dear Sir:

The attached invoices from Lepper & Co. are of course a re-presentation of bills originally forwarded last October.

Most of the work involved came about by reason of emergent repairs that had to be effected at the school. Among other things the hot water system broke down completely and it was found that quite apart from repairs being needed to the jacket heater, that certain lines and most of the taps were completely worn out and incapable of being repaired. Accordingly repairs to this phase of our hot water supply were effected. This involved a great deal of the material on invoice including new flue pipes from the jacket heater. While dealing with the hot water system repairs were effected to the toilets through the buildings and in addition several leaky valves on the heating system were either repaired or replaced.

The appendix shows a crane check valve that had to be secured and fitted in the pipe line leading from the pump to the water storage tank. The old valve was worn out and was allowing the water to leak back into the well.

The bill as a whole can be certified as correct and came about because after twenty years of use the breakdown of one portion necessarily resulted in trouble in other directions.

The Rev. R.J. Stealey, Principal of the Indian Residential School at Morley has requested that certain new equipment be purchased for the school as under:

One new Connor washer (commercial size) costing about $800.00. I am informed that the present machine is practically worn out, will not last much longer and cannot be further repaired.

Mr. Stealey also pointed out that he would like to get 10 new institutional beds which will cost approximately $125.00 each, less mattresses, but in this connection he says he could use Air Force double deck cots which he thinks can be purchased for about $8.50 each, less mattresses, which can be purchased from the salvage department at about $2.50 each mattress.

I would ask that immediate consideration be given to these various requests.

Re: Electric wiring
Morley Indian Residential School

Rev. H.J. Staley, principal at the Morley Indian Residential School has brought to my attention the condition of the electric wiring in the school residence building. He has written me requesting that consideration be given to the necessary re-wiring. A copy of Mr. Staley's letter is attached hereto.

Recently I looked over this situation and I find the wiring referred to is quite old and is very brittle. I think it should be thoroughly gone over by an electrician.

As this work might run into quite a sum of money I thought I should write to you before calling out an electrical firm to give a detailed estimate of the work and materials required.

However if you grant me permission I will ask for an estimate and submit it for your approval.

Morley, Alta.  
Jan. 1st. 1946

Dear Mr. Iredale,

I have become alarmed at the condition of some of the electric wiring at the school and examination of some of it reveals that there is a basis for worry. Many of the rooms are lighted by old fashioned drop cords and these with the sockets have been in use for twenty years with the result that the wiring is very brittle and the insulation in most cases gone. Other wiring leading to some of the machinery should be gone over and I would request that something be done to deal with what could easily turn into a serious situation.

Wiring installed at the Mission House at the same time, by the same people, has recently been the cause of a few thousand dollar fire. I would request then that sixty drop cords and sockets be renewed, or better still, that in some places in the school, a new system of lighting altogether be installed. The sewing room, office, dispensary, staff dining room and sitting room should all have modern lighting.

Your attention to the matter would be appreciated although I am not in the position to give you any figure as to cost at the present.

Yours Truly,

(Sgd.) E.J.Staley

Ottawa

The manufacturers have advised us that these are of second quality because there are some abrasive marks on the floor covering, but the moment the merchandise is waxed these marks will come out and we felt that you might not object to our doing this.

The price will be 5¢ per square yard less and if you feel that our action is satisfactory, will you please advise Rev. E.J. Staley, Principal of the Indian Residential School, Morley, Alberta, why this merchandise has a second mark on it.

Dear Mr. Pugh:

The matter of fire fighting and adequate protection of life and property at the Morley Indian School has been emphasized by the visit of Mr. Clark Chidlow of the American LaFrance Foamite Co., Calgary, who recently checked our equipment and made suggestions for more effective control of fire.

We need a better system of alarm. At present our alarm is a continuous ringing of a system of inside bells and an outside horn that is also used for the routine changes of duty during the day, and because of this loses much of its effectiveness as an alarm for fire. A distinctive siren, for fire only, would certainly increase the possibility of all the occupants of the building getting out safely in case of a sudden fire.

The installation of such a siren would not only be a protection for the School, but might also be of invaluable assistance in the control of fire in other buildings in the area.

The cost of such a siren as quoted by Mr. Chidlow is $67.50. This is without the cost of installation which would possibly amount to $50.00 more. In view of the increased protection which such a system of alarm would give I believe this expenditure would be fully justified; and, if it meets with your approval, I hope this suggestion may be passed on for the consideration of the Department.

Sincerely yours,

G. Roy Ingham,
Principal
