INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH, DEPT OF MINES AND RESOURCES, OTTAWA, ONT.

I beg to advise that recently on a visit from Mr Clark Chidlow, representing the American La France Fire Engine and Foamite Co., of Calgary, I took the opportunity of having Mr Chidlow check over the Morley Indian Residential School, requesting him to collaborate with the Rev G. Roy Inglis, Principal of the above school, with a view to ascertaining the condition of his fire-fighting equipment, and general fire protection for this school.

As a result of this visit, I have received the enclosed correspondence from the Principal which sets forth what is considered to be essential in the line of extinguishers for full protection at this school.

It will be observed from the recommendations made by Mr Chidlow that a further 5 new extinguishers of the "Foamite" type should be provided to be placed in the following strategic places in the school building:

1. Basement of the Outside Class Room building.
2. Entrance to Class Rooms upstairs, adjacent to each room.
3. Kitchen hallway.
4. Furnace room.
5. Main entrance hallway to Residential Building.

Prices quoted by the Western Supply and Manf Co. of Calgary, Alta for the above type of "Foamite" extinguisher is $25.15 each for lots of four or more, prices quoted being F.O.B. Calgary, Alta.

The Principal's action in having the several extinguishers that were found to be un-useable, eight in all, is recommended to the Branch for the approval of the expenditure that will be entailed, and it is further recommended that the new extinguishers requested be authorized.

A further letter from the Principal of the above school is also attached suggesting that a Fire Alarm siren be provided, and in discussing this matter with the Rev Inglis, I am inclined to accept his recommendation in the matter, as it would appear that bell ringing has lost its value as a fire protection medium, the siren would also be a warning to the Community at large, being situated in close proximity to the hospital and Agency premises.

To page 2.
At the present time, this school is equipped with a fire bell ringing system at the rear doors of the dormitories, which operate as the doors are opened, but not until. The main bell is used for calling staff and pupils to classes etc., and the Church bell is used for church purposes, hence it is thought that bells around this school have lost their value as a fire warning alarm.

The cost of the suggested Siren is quoted in the Principals letter attached.

May the foregoing suggestions and recommendations be considered as outlined, and this office advised, please.

J.E. Fugh
Superintendent

RE: Plastering of Class-rooms,
Morley Residential School.

In connection with the above matter, it is advised that under authority of file 119-1-5(WT 1) of Sept. 30/47, Mr. H.E. Wright, was employed to carry out this work.

The classrooms were stripped of the old plaster and a start was made on the ceiling of the West classroom. It was found that the lath was not durable enough to carry the weight of plaster. The reason being that in the original construction of the building, strips of \( \frac{1}{2} \) by \( \frac{1}{4} \) were nailed across the ceiling joists which are of 1 x 10 and the laths were then nailed to the 1 x \( \frac{1}{2} \) strips. It was noted that the weight of the plaster had pulled these strips together with the laths, loose. The space between the laths was also found to be insufficient with the result that when the new plaster was applied that the same buckling would occur as had taken place with the old plaster. As the job had been started, the writer undertook to provide lath wire and stone board to recondition the ceilings in both classrooms and the partition between. The laths on the ceiling together with the strips were entirely removed, and in one classroom, metal laths were used, in the other, stone board. The reason for the difference being that we were unable to procure sufficient for both rooms of either material. Mr. Wright, because of his contacts with building supply firms, was asked to obtain this material. The total cost of this extra material is $123.47 and was paid for in cash by Mr. Wright for which, together with his contract price of $650.00, a voucher will be submitted in due course.

The writer trusts that the Branch will concur in this action.

Dear Sir:

We hereby submit our tender to take out the old hot water tank and jacket heater in the Morley Indian School and install in its place, the following: for the sum of $375.00.

A new 30x120 hot water storage tank, shall be 1" and heads 2". This tank to be installed about 18" above the present pneumatic cold water tank and to be placed on a 2½" pipe stand. To install this tank it will be necessary to make an opening in the north side of the pump house and of course replace same when the tank is placed in position.

In the above figure we have estimated on heating the water with a Red Head, Taco or equal, water heater. This heater is a unit in itself with steam coils and has a heating capacity of 245 Imperial Gallons per hour. Raising the temperature of the water 100 degrees.

We have estimated on making connections to the steam outlet of each boiler carrying a 2½" line to the heater, trapping the condensation and discharging into the present condensation pump and receiver.

The hot water circulating pipe from this heater to the tank to be 2½".

We find that coal fed hot water heaters of this size required for this job are not made at the present time but it is the writer's opinion that the steam heating arrangement as specified above would be more satisfactory. This heater would be placed above the condensation pump thereby taking up no room, in front of the boilers. It would also eliminate the smoke pipe. We also believe that the maintenance cost would be reduced; the only attention that it would require would be that it would have to be taken out once a year and cleaned.

Yours truly,

Re: Branch File 119-1-5 (E.1) July 22nd 1948.
School Buildings, Morley Indians; School.

We have for acknowledgement the above referenced Branch letter, requesting further information as to type of school building required, as additional accommodation at the above school.

The writer had in mind when making tentative recommendation for day school provision, that a building similar to that now in use as a class room be provided, which would have two class rooms over a basement, that would contain a workshop, furnace etc.

Since discussing the matter with you, Mr. Uddick has made his survey, and has probably made some definite recommendations in general on this school, and we are of the opinion, that before deciding anything in the matter, it would as well to know what his views are in the matter of this school in general. Further accommodation for teachers would be required, up to four teachers and perhaps this could be provided as a unit with any new two class room building that might be erected in this programme. This may be covered in Mr. Uddick's report to the Branch.

The writer is treating this matter entirely from a day school angle, with provision only by the school for mid-day meal.

A re-designed building similar to the two room day schools now being erected with provision for sleeping quarters, bath rooms and electric lighting facilities should be considered, and such a building might be erected for approximately $45,000.00, at present costs.

Some provision should be made for increasing the kitchen facilities at the present school.

Respectfully submitted for your consideration.

John L. Hugh,
Superintendent,
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agencies.

August 12, 1948.

Re: Morley Indian Residential School

Your file 119-1-5 (A.1) of July 22.

Attached is copy of a letter just received from Superintendent J. L. Pugh, which is self-explanatory. Though we have no copy of Mr. Ruddick's report, we are of the opinion that he did not make any specific recommendations with regard to the method of providing more classroom facilities at Morley.

Mr. Pugh is now of the opinion that a classroom block, based on the standard plan for a two-room day school similar to the one to be constructed at Sarcee, but enlarged and re-designed to provide three classrooms and facilities for four teachers, would meet the need at Morley. There should be, of course, a full basement. The present two room classroom block would be retained as such, giving five rooms in all, or it could be made into a large one room classroom by removal of the partition.

Based upon the estimated cost of a one room day school, the cost of the above building would be $45,000.00 or more. Superintendent Pugh is placing an item in the Story House Estimates for $60,000.00.

Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Morley Indian Residential School
Stony-Sarcee Indian Agency,
Province of Alberta, Electoral District of Calgary West.

Funds have been provided in the current year's appropriation for painting the main school building, the Principal's residence and the outbuildings at the above mentioned residential school, and the materials required have been purchased by the Departmental Purchasing Agent. Superintendent J.E. Pugh has now submitted the following tenders for the work:

(1) Applicators Limited, 402 - 10th St., N.W.,
    Calgary, Alberta..........................$2,106.00

(2) E.C. Wright, Calgary, Alberta.................$1,750.00

(3) William Sigalet & Co., Ltd., 214 Burns Bldg., 8th Ave. & 2nd St., Calgary,
    Alberta.................................$1,290.00

Superintendent Pugh states that the above are the only tenders that he could obtain for the work, as the Morley Residential School is located approximately 40 miles from Calgary, and there are no painters in the immediate vicinity.

It would be appreciated if the Minister would approve acceptance of the lowest tender in the amount of $1,290.00.

PP/ST

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Morley Indian Residential School,
Stony-Sarcee Indian Agency, Province
of Alberta, Electoral District of
Calgary West

Alterations are required to the kitchen at
the above mentioned residential school, and the
materials needed have been purchased through the
Departmental Purchasing Agent. Superintendent
J.E. Pugh has received the following quotations
for the labour:

(1) Mr. A. Gray, 1115-9th St.E., Calgary, Alta.
Day Labour only - Foreman................$1.85 per hour
Carpenters............. 1.47 "
Labourers............. 1.00 "
Plasterers............. Union Rates.
Plus 12% of total payroll, to cover Workmen's
Compensation, Insurance, Transportation and use
of power tools. Payroll to be met 1st and 15th
of the month. Estimated time to finish work,
8 weeks.

(2) Mr. R. Rolston, 3804-13th Ave.W., Calgary, Alta.
Day Labour - Foreman...............$1.75 per hour
Carpenters............. 1.47 "
Labourers............. 1.00 "
Estimated total amount of job by the above party
$1,270.00.

(3) N.F. Mitchell, Cochrane P.O., Alberta.
Day Labour - Foreman...............$1.70 per hour
Carpenters............. 1.47 "
Labourers............. 1.00 "
Estimated total amount for job, $1,295.00.
In submitting the above tenders, Superintendent Pugh wrote as follows:

"The estimated total time to complete this work varies from 5 weeks to 8 weeks, and all three men quoting figured about a 5 to 6 man crew for the job, an estimated daily rate total of approximately $6.50 per day, the school to provide accommodation.

Of the three quoting, Mr. Gray appears to be the more businesslike, but we feel would be more costly. Mr. Mitchell is the next choice, a local type of carpenter and doing good work in the district, and we believe capable of doing this work.

All those quoting will undertake the complete job, inclusive of plastering, we to provide all materials and gravel."

In view of Superintendent Pugh's recommendation, it would be appreciated if the Minister would approve acceptance of the tender of N.F. Mitchell, Cochrane P.O., Alberta. This town is located near the school.

PP/ST

The late Rev. George Hollowell had for years in contemplation the establishment of an Orphanage in the North West, chiefly for the benefit of the numerous children who had been left friendless by the small-pox epidemic, and was about taking definite steps in the matter when his tragic death occurred. Two or three years later the enterprise was taken up by his son, the Rev. John Hollowell, with, it is understood, no other aim except that which he voluntarily given by friends of the Indians in the Methodist Church, the Missionary Board feeling unable to make an annual grant, in view of the other claims of the work. It appears that land was purchased with the consent of the Government, and that application was made for a grant of some £1000, so as to afford sufficient room for a suitable building. Mr. Hollowell proceeded with the work, securing a large portion of the land, erecting a small building, supplied with firewood, and opened the Home for the reception of orphan children. The Department has informed that this was all done largely at his own expense, and from the time the enterprise began until the autumn of 1892 he expended some £2500 more than he had received from all sources.

OTTAWA, 19th February, 1901

The Secretary:

Memo re water supply for McDougall Orphanage.

Dr Lafferty showed me a communication from Mr Ricks, the owner of Lot 7 Morley Settlement, which adjoins the school lot, in which he demands the sum of $1,000.00 for the privilege of using the water from the spring on that lot. Lot 7 contains 61 1/2 acres, for which Ricks paid $11, receiving his Patent on the 7th June last. The Department has, for the past two years been endeavoring to obtain the use of this spring for the past two years, as there is no water available on Lot 8, the school lot, and Mr Ricks has given his ultimatum that if his offer is not accepted, he will prevent the school from taking water therefrom.

I think that Mr Ricks' proposition is most unreasonable, and is, I understand, made because he has had some disagreement with the Rev. Mr McDougall and thinks that he is in a position to force the Department to pay him his price. Lot 8 was patented to the Methodist Church on the 28th Nov., 1894, my Ex having been set apart by Order-in-Council for the use of Orphanage and Training School for Indian children. This Lot contains 1876 acres.

It was a mistake in the first instance placing the school where it is, with no available water supply, and the Church should have taken steps long ago to secure perpetual use of the spring.
I think the question of price should be submitted to arbitration and if Ricks will not consent to this, steps should be taken by the Department to expropriate Lot 7, or at least the portion North of the road on which the spring is situated. I think this could be done as it is in the interest of the Government to use the spring, as the school cannot be carried on without the water supply.

[Signature]

The school is short of facilities in their present form, and this additional acreage is really needed for this purpose.

The Rev. Mr. Oakley, Principal of the McDougall Orphanage, submits a proposition from Mr. Frank Ricks to exchange the southern part of Lot 7, Norleyville Settlement, containing 362 acres for Sec. 18, T.35, R. 6, W. of the 5th Meridian, containing 640 acres, which he says would be a very valuable addition to the school property.

In addition to this the Department purchased the northern portion of Lot 7, containing 250 acres, which gives them a total area of 1426 acres, which should be ample for the school, and there does not appear to be any necessity for obtaining this additional piece of land. Farming can never be successfully carried on at this school, and they have all the land they need for stock-raising.

Plans, reports and approximate estimates of cost of the proposed waterworks and sewage system for the Morley Indian Boarding School have been prepared and received from Mr. L. G. Casewell, Engineer of Calgary, Alta.

The water plans recommend a supply being taken from a spring numbered 5 on his plan situated at a distance of 6000 feet South West of the proposed school site. This spring is said to be of exceptionally good water with a discharge of 135 gallons per hour or 3,240 gallons per day which is an ample supply. Reservoir proposed will hold 110,000 gallons or a full supply for five days or a limited supply for ten or fifteen days.

The supply is by gravitation with ample head and is sufficient for all domestic and school purposes as well as affording a limited hydrant supply for fire purposes.

Springs Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4 although considerable nearer the school site are not recommended as they are not constant.

septic tank with a gravel filter bed in second compartment
and the discharge is disposed of by discharging into the river
or by seepage into the subsoil.

or a total of $4,692.88

SPECIFICATION OF MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP.

Excavation and Backfill.
1. Take out excavation for Tank to the depth shown on the drawings and of sufficient size to leave room for the outside forms for the Concrete. If necessary, it shall be sufficiently shored or braced to prevent any caving. Evenly level off the bottom. Backfill behind tank walls, and any parts excavated below grade to be refilled with selected gravelly material watered and thoroughly rammed. If any water is encountered in excavation, the Contractor shall remove same before proceeding with the work. Under no circumstances must concrete be placed in position under water. Any rock encountered will be paid for as an extra as hereinbefore provided. If, however, a boulder less than half a cubic yard that can be removed without blasting is encountered, that shall not be classified as rock. After completion and removal of the forms, excavation to be solidly backfilled around the walls and well rammed into place.

Concrete.
2. Concrete shall be 1 : 2½ : 4 mix, placed to forms and dimensions shown on the plans. The roof of the Tank shall be reinforced. If the foundation is found to be soft, the floor also shall be reinforced and the work paid for as an extra. Evenly float to a smooth finish the floor, roof and exposed walls and neatly round off corners. Build baffle wall with two pieces reinforcing steel as shown. Manholes to be formed in roof and other finished openings including inlet to tank, two outlets from first chamber, and outlet from tank, all as shown. Provide and set in place two 90 degree elbows as outlets from first chamber of Tank to second chamber. Build the wall around filtering material, carry the projection all round so that the sewage may overflow from all sides, as
shown on the Drawings. The Concrete shall consist of cement, sand and broken stone or coarse screened gravel mixed in the proportions by measure of four parts broken stone to two and a half parts sand, and one part cement by volume. Pit run gravel, if clean and well graded, may be used. The aggregates shall be measured in proper measuring boxes, except that a sack of cement shall be considered as one cubic foot. The broken stone must be capable of passing through a two inch ring. It shall be perfectly clean. No forms must be removed until the concrete deposited has stood for thirty six hours.

When the concrete is mixed by hand, the mixture of sand and broken stone or gravel is first to be spread in a thin layer on a timber platform, then the cement spread on the top thereof, then the cement mixed thoroughly whilst dry, after which the proper quantity of clean water is added gradually while the mass is being turned over, and mixed until the mortar thus formed covers the concrete or broken stone or gravel entirely, and until the concrete attains a proper consistency. If broken stone be used with gravel, it should be wet thoroughly and added to the wet mass during the mixing. Concrete shall be made with so much water that comparatively light tamping will be required to cause the mortar to fill all the interstices of the stone. Immediately after mixing, the concrete shall be conveyed to place in such manner that there shall be no separation of the different ingredients. It shall be rammed or tamped thoroughly in layers not exceeding twelve inches in thickness, and otherwise agitated by suitable tools so as to produce a thoroughly compact concrete of maximum density, and so that all interstices are filled; and so that the concrete presents a smooth, finished, unbroken mortar surface without exposed stones when the forms are removed, whether the exterior of the mass be mortar alone or concrete. Should any concrete receive its initial set before being placed, it shall be rejected and removed. Should, during construction,
any surface of concrete be allowed to harden or dry before
the other concrete is placed thereon, it shall be swept
perfectly clean with brooms, then wetted thoroughly with
clean water, and covered with a thin layer of one to one grout,
so as to make a perfect contact between the old and the new
work, and thus ensure that the mass will be truly monolithic.
The forming of such dry surfaces shall always be prevented
if practicable. If the walls are stepped below their finished
height, a two by four check shall be made in the center of
the wall as a key for the next layer, and a similar check in
floors underneath the centre of walls. All concrete should
be kept damp until thoroughly set by drenching it, or the
forms containing it, twice a day. If, notwithstanding extreme
care in placing and ramming the concrete, imperfections are
found when the forms are removed, such imperfections to be
floated over with mortar composed of one part Portland Cement,
and two parts sand, but no plastering of any kind will be
permitted. All surfaces of concrete which are to remain in
contact with earth backfill shall receive a heavy coat of coal
tar applied hot. Where iron pipes pass through concrete the
coating to be scraped off the pipes.

The reinforcing steel for tank cover to be of plain round
rods nine feet long and half an inch in diameter, spaced six
inches centre to centre. It shall have an ultimate tensile
strength of not less than sixty thousand nor more than seventy
thousands pounds, and an elastic limit of not less than
thirty thousand pounds, with a minimum elongation of twenty
two per cent in an eight inch test piece. If displaced when
pouring the concrete, or from other cause, the concrete shall
be removed and the steel brought to correct position. Any rust
on the steel must be removed.
Cement.

3. All cement used on the work shall be of approved manufacture, and capable of complying with the following conditions: Extra finely ground Portland Cement, weighing not less than 112 lbs nor more than 120 lbs per imperial struck bushel when lightly run into a measure, and when shaken through a sieve having 5776 meshes to the square inch the residue shall not exceed three per cent; it shall be capable of maintaining a tensile strain of 400 lbs per square inch of sectional area seven days after gauging, and 500 lbs per square inch twenty-eight days after gauging, the sieves being prepared from standard wire of the size .004 inch in diameter; it shall be woven, the cloth being carefully mounted in the frame without distortion. The specific gravity of the cement shall be less than 3.10. It shall have been freshly ground, and if it has deteriorated through age or exposure shall not be used.

Sand.

4. The sand shall be clean and sharp and not too fine. If necessary, it shall be washed.

Lead and Gasket.

5. Lead shall be No.1. Pig Lead, soft and suitable for run joints. Gaskets to be best Italian stranded hemp yarn. No oakum to be used.

Filtering Material

6. Deposit in the space enclosed by the walls in end chamber of Tank, a layer one foot deep of field stones or "niggerheads" from six to ten inches in size. Cover the layer with a second layer of stones from four to six inches in size, to a depth of one foot. Cover the whole with a final layer of small broken or field stone from one inch to two inches in size, to a depth of six inches. The whole of the filtering material to be clean and free from dirt, dust or chippings. If necessary, the material to be washed. Absolutely no dirt will be permitted in the filter.
Sludge Bed.

7. Excavate for a sludge bed where shown, fifteen feet wide by twenty-five feet long on bottom, with an average depth of two feet, and side slopes one and a half to one. A layer of gravel three to four inches in size to be spread over the bottom to a depth of one foot. The excavated material to be deposited around the sides of the bed and evenly sloped off.

Extra Backfill.

8. In all cases where the depth of backfill does not cover the pipes or tank by eight feet, place extra backfilling to such depth. The amount of backfill may be determined from the drawing showing profile of sewer pipe line.

Pipe Lines.

9. Excavate for and lay six inch C.I. Sewer Pipe from connection with soil pipe at School building to Tank as shown on the plans, and thence to outlet in trenches.

Allow for connecting six inch sewer with soil pipe.

The pipes shall be of standard thickness, spigot and socket pattern, of best quality, smooth and round. Dig bell holes for the hubs so that the pipes shall rest solidly throughout. Pipes shall be jointed with hemp and lead thoroughly staved up and caulked in a workmanlike manner and perfectly tight under pressure. Properly build in, and make watertight around, the inlet and outlet pipes of tank.

Manholes.

10. Build two concrete manholes two by four from the Tank to the surface of the ground to enable a man to remove sludge from the inside of the Tank. Provide two C.I. Manhole covers to be laid to position on a bed of cement mortar. Provide two manhole covers for Tank. Provide and set two ventilating pipes in Tank of four inch Galvanized W.S. Pipe with Plain Ventilator and Cowle Ventilator as shown, properly connected, and carried up three feet above surface of ground. Excavate for, and build in, a concrete manhole two by four where shown on sewer pipe line. Provide and set S.I. Manhole cover.

Form a "half pipe" channel in six inch concrete floor, eight...
inches in diameter, from inlet to outlet, and to the same grade as the pipes, so that the flow of sewage can be openly observed.

Trenches for Liquid Sewage.

11. Excavate a series of five trenches as shown on the drawing, not to be backfilled, as an outlet for the liquid to filter away. Form same three feet deep from surface of ground, with sides cut one and a quarter to one, slopes and excavation piled evenly on both sides. The width of trenches to be one and a half feet (1.5) Excavate one foot deep to outlet of pipe in trench. The trenches will be two feet deep below sewer pipe outlet, making a total depth of three feet.

Inspection and Testing.

12. On completion, the work may be inspected and the Contractor is required to flush the system to determine that the same is in working order.

Completion.

13. Perform any cleaning up necessary to leave the premises tidy at completion.

SPECIFICATIONS OF MATERIAL AND WORKMANSHIP.

Reservoir.
1. The Reservoir site is a natural one as shown on the Drawings, and when the Dam is completed will have a capacity of 110,000 gallons. Thoroughly clear away all dirt or matter that might be a source of pollution to the water, from the site. Grub down to solid earth.

Dam.
2. Build an earthen dam according to dimensions shown on Plans, with side slopes two to one. Excavate foundation for dam one foot, provide and set a layer of selected cobble stones from six to ten inches in size and ram solid. Provide and set in position Rip Rap to protect the sides of dam as shown on the Plans, composed of large cobble or field stones. The Dam must be formed with a puddle core kept full of water during construction, fine material to be selected and turned into the center. No concrete to be placed under water. Pound and tamp the dam into shape, and solidly. Mix concrete in the proportions (1 : 2½ : 5) one of Cement, two and a half of clean sharp sand, and five of broken stone of a size approximately two inches. Mix and perform the concrete work strictly in accordance with the conditions contained in Specification for Materials and Workmanship for Sewage Works of this Contract. The Cement and other ingredients in accordance with the same Specification. Build concrete in Dam and Spillway as shown on the drawings. The quantity of concrete is three and a half cubic yards approximately.

Spillway.
Form Spillway as shown, and provide and set in position two inch planking in slot, and form trench connecting with creek downstream to overflow from spillway.
Excavate Pipe Trenches.

3. Excavate for pipe laying, about 2300 cubic yards to true alignment and grade as set out. Backfill and ram solidly the earth after the pipes have been laid, properly jointed and inspected. Where the pipe has not the necessary eight feet in depth of backfilling to cover, provide extra backfilling and thoroughly ram over the trenches with sides evenly sloped. The amount of backfilling extra may be ascertained from the drawing showing profile of pipe line.

Laying Pipes.

4. Provide and lay two inch Galvanized W.I. Pipe of Standard thickness and approved manufacture. Form small pile of stones, firmly fixed, to support pipe intake as shown on the drawing. Provide and set over end of pipe, a thin wire screen, to prevent obstructive matter entering the pipe. Build in two inch Gate Valve with valve box and key complete, and having bronze fitted valve with hub or flanged ends, and bronze spindle, to open by turning to the left, as shown on the downstream side of dam. Provide and lay one and a half inch Galvanized W.I. pipe of standard thickness from the Point "A" on plan to School Site, connected with two inch pipe by a standard reducer. All joints to be securely screwed and jointed with waterproof cement. Allow for connecting one and a half inch pipe to water service pipe in School building.

Report of L.G. Casewell, C.E. on Water Supply and Sewerage System, New Boarding School, Stony Indian Reserve, Morley, Province of Alberta.

To J.D. McLean Esq.,
Acting Deputy Supt: General of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir,

Water Supply.

Acting under instructions, I left Calgary on July 25th for the purpose of making a Survey and collecting data with which to formulate a scheme for Water Supply and Sewerage Disposal in connection with the new boarding school, Morley.

LOCATION.

The School is to be built on a site approved by the Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs, 1500 feet West of the Indian Agency Headquarters, and 1100 feet South West of the Steel Bridge carrying the main automobile road from East to West over the Bow River.

This is an ideal location.

FORMATION.

The formation is of gravel, sandstone and blue shale outcrop.

DRAINAGE.

The drainage is natural, any storm water is readily absorbed by the gravel, and the School will be built on rising table land.

SOURCES OF SUPPLY.

There are five Springs in the vicinity, as shown on the Plan.
No.1, and the Bow River traverses East and West at a distance of 1000 feet North of the School.

Springs Nos' 1, 2, 3 & 4, are inadequate in their supply. With the exception of Spring No.1, they dry up at intervals during the summer, or seep away through the gravelly formation.

The necessary amount of 'head' could not be acquired by adopting these Springs. A pumping engine would have to be used, and the supply of water would be insufficient, taking into consideration that sixty per cent goes to waste and cannot be re-used, to warrant the use of a hydraulic ram.

This Spring is a frequent halting place for Indians. Many call to drink and water their horses.

SPRING NO. 5:

This is a large Spring, situated 6000 feet Southwest of the School Site, to which I have run a line as shown on the Plan. The Chief of the Bearpaw Tribe of Indians on this Reserve states that it has never been known to fail for 18 years, that it is the best drinking water the Indians are acquainted with, and that the Indians themselves would favour this Spring being utilised as the School supply.

I have computed the discharge, and find it to be 135 gallons per hour, or 3,240 gallons per day of 24 hours, which is more than ample.

The water forms a creek which discharges into the pond as shown on Plan No.1. This pond is generally about two feet deep, and the water finds its drainage through the gravel below.

I consider that this Spring should be utilised as the Source
of Supply.

RESERVOIR AND DAM.

I suggest, therefore, that an earthen dam and reservoir be constructed below the Spring as shown on the Plan No.1, details on Drawings Nos' 4, 5 & 6. The reservoir to hold 110,000 gallons, or five days supply.

PIPE LINE.

A two inch pipe line is laid from the intake, having a screen at the end, and tilted on a pile of stones as shown, to prevent silt or obstructive matter entering the pipe.

At the point "A" on the plan, or pipe line, the pipe is reduced to $1\frac{1}{2}$ inches to ensure it running full, and as a considerable amount of pressure or velocity, due to gravity, is obtained from here on, this pipe will do its work well.

OUTLET & DISCHARGE.

Assuming an elevation of 4043 feet to be well within the upper story of the School building, by the use of the formulae given on Drawing No.3, (Water Supply Chart), we have a discharge of 12 gallons per minute at this point.

This gives a satisfactory supply through all taps or openings within the building.

If it is desired to fix Fire Hydrants around the building there will also be a good supply, with the necessary amount of pressure for use in case of fire.
SEWERAGE DISPOSAL.

SEWER PIPE & SEPTIC TANK.

The disposal of sewage and other wastes can be suitably conducted by means of a six inch C.I. sewer pipe to a Septic Tank of the design shown on drawings 7, 8 & 9.

It is proposed to locate this Tank under a depth of eight feet of earth as a guard against frost, with two manholes from the surface down, and a concrete manhole at a distance of 400 feet from the point of commencement as shown on the Profile.

DETAILS OF TANK & TREATMENT.

The sewage can be made to enter the settling chamber at a grade of 2.0%, which gives a satisfactory velocity into the tank. With this grade the pipe will be self cleansing and will not require flushing.

The sewage passes under a "baffle wall" before flowing into a second settling pocket in which it comes in contact with air and water before overflowing on to the gravel filter. The baffle wall, and the positions of the two outlets from the first chamber in relation to its inlet, ensures, when in action, a slow and steady movement of the sewage during preliminary sedimentation, and prevents splashing.

The air is excluded from this chamber when in action. Some of the industrious bacteria must live in water with a minimum amount of air, and have quiet surroundings.

The sewage now enters the second chamber with a lake-pocket for the further pleasure of the anaerobic or sea-going bugs before overflowing on the screened gravel filter.

A continual supply of fresh air enters and leaves this chamber.
through the vents as shown in sectional elevation, Drawing No.8. The fresh air, and water contained in the above mentioned pocket, supplies the necessary aerobic bacteria.

When the now partly purified sewage has risen 4 feet, it runs around the concrete four inch projection shown on plan and in section, which is designed to enable the sewage to overflow on to the filter from all sides.

OUTLET AND DISPOSAL.

After filtration through a bed of four feet of screened gravel, the sewage runs through the six inch outlet at a grade of .10% and discharges into the trenches, where it seeps away through the gravel.

ALTERNATIVE.

An alternative method would be to build a Cesspool of brick set in cement mortar with open joints. As, however, the use of trenches enables the liquid to be actually seen and better investigated should any defect appear throughout the system, and it cannot be definitely assumed, at present, that the nature of the sub-soil, at that depth, would facilitate a filtering disposal of the liquid, I have in the present case projected a series of trenches on the Plan for this purpose.

SLUDGE BED.

The sludge from the Tank is emptied through the manholes on the Sludge Bed where shown on the Plan, and the amount is not great. From one to two cubic yards per million gallons of sewage

Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your No. 409-11A of the 6th instant, with reference to the proposed buildings for a residential school at Morley. I note that you will prepare a rough sketch and forward it to the Department in due course. With reference to the water supply, I have to inform you that the Department had Mr. L. C. Caswell, C.E., of 33 Lineham Block, Calgary, make a report in 1914. He found four springs marked with a red dot on the enclosed plan—which were quite close to the site that was proposed for the new buildings at that time. Concerning these four springs, the engineer reports in part as follows: "They are inadequate in their supply, with one exception. They dry up at intervals during the summer or seep away through the gravelly formation. The necessary amount of 'head' could not be acquired by adopting these springs. A pumping engine would have to be used and the supply of water would be insufficient, taking into consideration that sixty per cent goes to waste and cannot be re-used, to warrant the use of a hydraulic ram."

The engineer refers to three of these four springs as having a flow of 135, 115 and 32 gallons per hour at certain seasons. I believe the site to which he refers is one selected by Mr. Inspector Markle in 1914, which is a few hundred feet distant and considerably higher than one suggested by Rev. T. Perrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian schools and hospitals.

The engineer reports at some length concerning the feasibility of securing a water supply from a large spring situated 6000 feet southwest of the proposed site and marked with a red cross on the enclosure. This spring apparently has excellent water and at that time had a flow of 135 per hour. The engineer recommended that this spring be utilized.
be utilized for the school and that a reservoir and dam be built and a pipe-line laid. The cost of this scheme was estimated at approximately $3400. The engineer drew plans in this connection and also prepared specifications for a sewerage disposal system the cost of which was estimated to be $1285.50.

As it was decided in August 1914 not to proceed with the erection of a school, no further action was taken in connection with the water supply or disposal systems.

I wish to add that there is a possibility of securing a supply of water from the C. P. R., who own and operate, I believe, a pump at the Bow River and have a large tank at Morley station. It might be advisable in the interest of economy to approach the railway company with a view to having them supply the water for the proposed new residential school.

Lot 8, Morleyville Settlement, patented from the Crown (Dominion) to the Methodist Church on the 26th day of November, 1894. Minerals were included. Methodist Church transferred back to Crown (Dominion). There was no reservation in this transfer as to minerals, therefore, they are now back in the Crown - see Certificate of Title from Methodist Church to Crown (Dominion) 32722, 1925.

MEMORANDUM:

I am in receipt of your memorandum of the 20th instant, Indian Affairs Branch file 119-1-6 (R.2) together with five Lands, Parks and Forests Branch files Nos. 64274, Volumes 1, 2 and 3 and file Nos. 156236, volumes 1 and 2, together with Mr. Gibson's memorandum to Mr. Hoey of the 10th idem.

Mr. Gibson has requested that these files be examined and advised as to whether there is any objection to letting Mr. Harvie, Deputy Minister of Lands and Mines, Edmonton, have the loan of them.

As requested in your said memorandum of the 20th instant, I have examined these files and I do not find anything contained therein that might prejudice the right of the Crown (Dominion) to the two lots in question, viz., part of lot 7 and all of lot 8, Morleyville Settlement, Alberta. These two lots are held by the Crown (Dominion) by virtue of duplicate Certificates of Title Nos. 32V58 and 32V72 respectively. These Certificates were obtained from your records for examination and are returned herewith. The lots in question, by reason of the fact that the Crown had title by Certificate of Title prior to the transfer to the Province of Alberta of its Natural Resources, pursuant to the Alberta Natural Resources Agreement Act, were retained by the Dominion by virtue of Section 18 thereof which, in part, reads as follows:

"Except as herein otherwise expressly provided, nothing in this agreement shall be interpreted as applying so as to affect or transfer to the administration of the Province (a) any lands for which Crown grants have been made and registered under the Land Titles Act of the Province and of which His Majesty the King in the right of His Dominion of Canada is, or is entitled to become the registered owner at the date upon which the agreement comes into force".

In my study of the files it was deemed advisable to determine the ownership of the minerals in these said lots and I am to advise you that the minerals underlying these lands are in the Crown (Dominion).

Dear Dr. Keenleyside:

When I was in Ottawa it was my intention to discuss with you the ownership of Lot 7, Morleyville Settlement, north of the roadway and the whole of Lot 8 in the same settlement.

By reason of the fact that this property was held under Certificate of Title it was retained by Canada upon the transfer of the natural resources. However, from the information we have we are of the opinion that the property should belong to the Province.

Upon a perusal of the records you will find that when acquiring the part of Lot 7 the consideration was the granting of patent to Frank Ricks for the North half of Section 18 and the North half of Section 20, Township 25, Range 5, West of the 5th Meridian and the sum of $1.00. Furthermore, that Lot 8 had been transferred to the Methodist Church with the usual habendum clause that upon the lands ceasing to be used for the express purpose for which they were granted, namely for the purpose of an orphanage and training school for Indian children, that title would again become vested in the Crown. The land having ceased to be used or required by the Methodist Church it was transferred back to the Crown on the 14th of October, 1920, the consideration being the sum of $1.00.

At no time does it seem that the Indians were in any way entitled to these lands under the terms of treaty.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Harvie:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of 30th September with regard to Lot 7, Morleyville Settlement, north of the highway, and that portion of Lot 8 in the same settlement lying north of the severance line, and I regret that I am unable to agree with your contention that the properties should belong to the Province of Alberta.

You point out that the said Lots which originally had been transferred to the Methodist Church, were re-transferred to the Crown on 14th October, 1929, on the grounds that they were no longer required by the Church, but you are apparently not aware that in 1928 the authorities of the Morley Indian Residential School applied to the Department of the Interior to have the Lots made available to the said school for pasturage purposes. Such request would, in the ordinary course of events, have been granted; but at the time it was made, no action could be taken for the Lots had been leased for a term of years expiring in 1934, and were therefore not available to the residential school. However, following the expiration of the said lease, the 1928 application was again brought forward, and as the Lots were considered necessary to the operation of the residential school, they were reserved for the Indian Affairs Branch for the purposes of the said school, and have continued to be used by the school to this date. As you are undoubtedly aware, the Morley Indian Residential School, while operated by the United Church of Canada, is subsidized by the Government of Canada.
While it is probable that at some future date the Lots in question will cease to be used for the purposes of the said school, I do not see that this would in any way alter the fact that as at the date of the transfer of the natural resources, the Lots were in an exempted class, and in any event, when the use of the Lots by the school comes to an end, it is our intention to add the Lots to the Stony Indian Reserve where they are urgently needed to provide additional grazing and agricultural land for that group of the Stony Band living north of the Bow River.

Under the circumstances above mentioned, I regret that it is impossible for us to recognize your claim that the Lots passed to the Province of Alberta under the terms of the Natural Resources Agreement.

Yours very truly,

H. L. KEENLEYSIDE

Deputy Minister.

Ottawa, January 29th, 1931.

Sir,

Referring to that portion of your letter of the 20th instant in which you suggest the advisability of not permitting the girls of the Morley Indian Residential School to go home during the annual holidays, I have to say that it is the general policy of the Department to allow the pupils whose homes are within a reasonable distance of the school leave of absence for holidays and it is thought that it would be undesirable to make exception in this case as the parents would, no doubt, strongly protest against not having their children during the holiday period. I would point out that, when the children are at their homes, they are under the care of their parents or guardians and they must accept responsibility for the children's care and conduct while under their charge.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Stony Indian Reservation, Canada

The Parents of this pupil both died when he was a child approximately two years old and since that time his home has been with Grand Uncle, Mr. Pousette. Mark is now aged 12 suffering with Anthrax, and wants Adam to help out here. The school have been asked about Adam's age. You will note the School Return for Sept. 1923 gave it as 12 yrs. Rev. Mr. Gibson, Principal of the School informs me that he has reliable information that would suggest Adam to be in his seventeenth year; that at his admission to school, his statement agreed with the proof of age, and evidently he was one year of age when enrolled.

Mark Pousette is a good provider, and very much attached to this boy, and I would recommend that permission be granted to discharge this pupil from school.

Sir,

Mrs. Morley Beaver, a Stony Indian woman, separated from her husband, has a child (a girl) four and one half years old, to support, and wishes her placed in the Indian Residential School here.

This child appears normally bright, but is unable to speak. Physically, she is normal with the exception of a slight stenosis of the pulmonary valve, probably congenital, which does not interfere with the normal activity of the child, and I judge it is not likely to do any damage.

I beg to recommend that she be admitted, although I did not want to admit her without submitting the facts to your attention. While her mother does the best a woman can for her, she will be better fed and clothed in the school, and when she becomes old enough to go to the Class room, she will learn to write. Otherwise she will have no means of expression. My main reason for recommending the admission is that she is normal mentally.

I beg to be advised at your earliest convenience.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
PB CALGARY, ALTA., March 23rd, 1935.

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention that while at Morley inspecting that Agency the matter of children attending the school came up. I have known of a great many cases where Indian children were attending school and they would be much better left out of school on account of ill health; and I have often noticed that although the general surroundings and the food were better in school, when they were allowed to go back home they would pick up in a few months. The question came up that if the Doctor finds that a child is not doing well in school, and as Medical Officer he is of the opinion that by bringing it home and getting it out into the fresh air it would do better, has he the authority to discharge the child, or would this have to be taken up with the Department? I was not sure on this point.

I have known medical men to give instructions to discharge certain children. This, of course, would only come up once in awhile. There are three girls at the Morley School at present who are T.B. bed patients and in my opinion they would do much better at home; At least no worse, as I do not suppose any of the three will live. I shall be glad to be advised on this question.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Of course, in all such cases, the Department should be advised at once of the reasons why the pupil has been sent home.

With all supplies laid in and the teachers on hand by the beginning of September, an epidemic of Black Measles became so acute that school could not be opened in September.

The full grant is respectfully requested because expenses during September have been practically as high as though the children were in residence. We have been compelled to hire all our labour during the busiest month for farm work we have. Also for the greater part of the time the school has been used as an emergency hospital, with the staff detailed to do the nursing.

Sir:-

Herewith I beg to submit the quarterly return for Morley Indian Residential School for the quarter ended September 30th.

During the above period we have had an epidemic of measles on the reserve & the school has been made use of as an overflow hospital, as the accommodation in the hospital proper was not sufficient to take care of all the patients who required attention. This of course entailed a great deal of extra work for the school staff & although the regular classes were not conducted there was practically the same amount or expense incurred during the quarter as would have been under ordinary circumstances.

I would respectfully recommend therefore that the full amount of the grant be paid, as requested in Mr. Staley's letter.

Morley, Alta., Jan. 6, 1938.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith the quarterly returns from the Morley Indian School.

Please note the admission of Kenneth Ebenezer, age 3. The father of this child is totally blind and unable to support his wife and family. He is unable to earn anything and they live entirely on a ration for two adults. The mother is a low grade moron, giving the children less care than a young coyote gets. In spite of all my efforts to the contrary, she keeps the house like a pigsty; the children are always filthy, and their inadequate clothing is in rags. Another child is expected any day.

The parents have applied for admission to the school of Kenneth, for the purpose of giving him proper food and clothing and lessening on themselves, a blind husband and half-wit wife, and I beg to urge that he be accepted.

It will be noted that this child is not included in the list for which grant is applied for. I beg to be advised as to whether he should be included in the return for the present quarter.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir:-

In submitting the attached application for admission to school of Gweneth Rider, age 4, I beg to explain that her mother died leaving 7 children. The eldest child is discharged from school, 4 are now in school, a baby has been given in adoption, and the father, from the wish to keep the family together as much as possible, asks to have this child in school.

This girl is a bright healthy youngster and there is nothing against her admission except her age. I beg to recommend that she be admitted as otherwise her father will have to give her to some other family, and he is very fond of his family.

Your obedient servant,
